ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned how to write a well crafted essay
Close-reading skills for short stories, and writing techniques, specifically, understanding conveying well-structured argument in different essay formats.

I read a lot of short stories, and some theory about the genre. As a result I feel I gained an understanding of the main characteristics of the short story, and what distinguishes it (besides its length) from the novel.
More importantly, I learned how to write at a college level.

This course helped me hone and refine my analytical writing skills, while also developing more ease with small-group academic discussions. Through exposure to a wide body of work, I felt that this class really broadened my appreciation of the short story in its many forms!
I learned how to close read, create strong arguments, and write research papers. We also discussed different theories on what makes a short story good, and read a wide variety of amazing stories.
My writing ability significantly improved thanks to this course, and I learned how to go about finding peer-reviewed sources for writing research papers.

In this ENGL 115 section (The Art of the Short Story, taught by Professor Daniel Diaz de la Rocha), I learned a lot about the art of the short story, and what makes a short story either work or not work. This class also really improved my writing organization, clarity, and brevity. I also honed my critical thinking and research skills. His class also developed the regular practice of writing with regular Discussion posts about the short stories we read. He also encouraged developing constructive peer review practices. Danny also provides excellent constructive feedback, and provides it in a manner that, while constructive, is not discouraging (and he always seems enthusiastic to read what you've written)!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The focus on short stories allowed the reading and writing topics to approach depths of complexity without requiring volumes of reading. The essay formats challenge writers to think in different ways about texts and to maintain strong writing practices regardless of the style of argument.

strengths:
- the readings (reading short stories is rarely terribly time consuming, so we were able to sample dozens of different authors, which was lovely)
- DANNY! Danny was easily the best English teacher Ive ever had. He is very good at facilitating discussion, and even better at asking the class hard questions to move the discussion along.

The course moved at a good pace and did a great job blending critical reading/analytical writing. I liked the discussion formats, but sometimes the discussions felt like they could have been a little less structuredi.e. we could have been given more freedom to structure the conversation according to our own thoughts about the stories. But on the whole, the course was quite well organized and executed.

The readings for the course were really great, and the class discussions were always engaging. I think one weakness was that we didn't have any time to workshop our final short story, so more feedback throughout that writing process would have been helpful.

Strengths: only relevant (and interesting) readings were assigned and everyone was engaged and participated in class, allowing for an in-depth discussion of each text.
Weaknesses: the only minor weakness was that more time could have been spent explaining the structure and writing style needed for each different essay type.

The top strength of this section of ENGL 115 is the Professor, Daniel Diaz de la Rocha! Each week, he selected engaging short stories to read to stimulate our personal critical viewpoints, thoughtful literary analysis, engaging class discussions, and thoughtful peer reviews. Danny also provides excellent constructive feedback, and provides it in a manner that, while constructive, is not discouraging (and he always seems enthusiastic to read what you've written)! (Another strength was the amazing classmates I had this semestera group that became surprisingly close and tight-knit throughout the semester! We genuinely looked forward to reading each other's Discussion posts and final short stories!)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I enjoyed the online seminar, though I do wish we had more student to student engagement.
I cant think of a COVID-related change in the course that didnt succeed.

The pre-class discussion board requirement went a very long way towards easing virtual participationnot only did it add another option of participation for those for whom it was harder to participate over Zoom, but it helped "break the ice" so to speak, i.e. overcome the awkwardness of Zoom that sometimes prohibits class discussions from really taking off in a virtual setting.

Professor Diaz de la Rocha organized the course materials on a semester calendar at the beginning of the semester, which made it helpful in planning the reading and writing assignments. He made all of the information readily accessible for a remote learning environment.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. The readings come alive in a very accessible way that develops through conversations in seminar. I felt myself grow as a writer as I had to adjust my trains of thought to meet the demands of the different prompts.
Absolutely. Learning about short stories while learning how to write undergraduate papers is a great introductory combination. I would especially recommend the course if Danny is teaching it again.
Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student no matter what their writing/literature background is, because I think everyone can learn something from this course.

Yes!! I was so excited to take this course and it was everything I had hoped for. You get to read a ton of incredible short stories, and by the end of the class it feels like you are familiar with a bunch of writers and different styles and structures of storytelling. The feedback I got throughout the semester improved my essays significantly, and the whole class made me want to try more English and creative writing courses in the future.

I would highly recommend this course with Danny - the short stories are all very fun to read and Danny is an excellent instructor. Getting to write your own short story at the end was also a great way to conclude the course.

Definitely! It's a unique literature seminar in that it's focused on the art of the short story instead of through the lens of long novels. I learned a lot about what makes a story either work or not work. This class also really improved my writing organization, clarity, and brevity. I also honed my critical thinking and research skills. Each week, Professor Danny selected engaging short stories to read to stimulate our personal critical viewpoints, thoughtful literary analysis, engaging class discussions, and thoughtful peer reviews. We also had the regular practice of writing with regular Discussion posts about the short stories we read. (Another strength was the amazing classmates I had this semestera group that became surprisingly close and tight-knit throughout the semester! We genuinely looked forward to reading each other's Discussion posts and final short stories!)

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Online discussion board to enrich our virtual class discussion
Live virtual lecture!

extras.title:
ENGL 115 02
        Art of the Short Story
